data.text: bivi-tent ek 2
What are the pros and cons of a Bivy and a tent. Which one do you recommend for 1 person?
Bivvy lighter great for stealth camping I really only get my tent out in the cooler months for me it's Bivvy and tarp
data.author: David Taylor

data.text: does that mean if I get a bivvy I still need a tarp? If so which tarp would you recommend? I saw some on Decathlon and they weighed a lot
data.author: Sarah Dee

data.text: my bivi it is heavier than my tent, saying that my tent is 900g üòÅ
data.author: Jason Bull

data.text: I don't use a tarp, get a good bivi, a thermarest matress, good sleeping bag, job done
data.author: Jason Bull

data.text: A tent. Bivvys are only slightly lighter than quality tents, less room to manoeuvre in, no chance of getting dressed, no room to stash items. No possibility to cook. Most take tarps along and then the potential weight advantage of the package is lost as well. Only real advantage: less obvious/less visible. That's it.
data.author: Axel Knobbe

data.text: A lot of variables. Length of ride and climate really. In a wet cold climate, a Bivy and all your gears gonna get pretty miserable in a few days. You can get a good tent that weighs less than a kilo. Any fool can be uncomfortable. That‚Äôs the easy bit.
data.author: Alex Gee

data.text: Conditions
data.author: Andy McMahon

data.text: next week in Europe for starters. Holland, France, Belgium. Weather looks dry
data.author: Sarah Dee

data.text: tarp and bivy bag
data.author: Andy McMahon

data.text: tent
data.author: Matt Hill

data.text: dependant on environment I prefer hammock
data.author: Andy McMahon

data.text: tent for sure. No fly sheet if you want to see the stars. A tent gives you a bit more space & privacy and will be better if the weather does change. Also will prevent biting insects (the reason why no sane person will bivvi in Scotland in summer unless the weather is guaranteed to be windy üòâüëç)
data.author: Rosie Baxendine

data.text: Is it going to rain?
data.author: Dave Ansell

data.text: Bivi, stealth wild camp üëå
data.author: Jason Bull

data.text: I took a bivvy bag and a tent on my recent trip. Didn't use the tent as weather was great to bivvy in. But would've been a good back up if weather was bad. It did rain one night but stopped off next day and dried my kit out on a church lawn. Hopefully that's allowed...
data.author: Andrew Bucknall

data.text: only mesh from a tent (no fly) is basically a bivvy, if you have a sleeping bag on. I really don't see a point of carrying a bivvy, or both like you did. In the time you unroll a bivvy, stuff your sleeping bag and a mat in there, you can put up inner-only tent setup. I mean, don't get me wrong, if you like bivvying, by all means, do it, I'm just stating the practical obvious, for the sake of OP reply.
data.author: Ivan Perak

data.text: it was less hassle packing up the next morning, hence just using a bag and not getting the tent out.
data.author: Andrew Bucknall

data.text: spot on üëç

data.text: Summer bivi, autumn, winter, spring 1 person tent
data.author: Phill Rashleigh

data.text: Sarah, have a look on YouTube at The Outdoor Gear Review channel. There are loads of videos with gear reviews etc. I‚Äôm certain he‚Äôs got some on bivies v tents. He‚Äôs got well organised playlists so shouldn‚Äôt take long to find. He‚Äôs also agenda free, so pretty objective.
data.author: Bernie Hamilton

data.text: thank you!

data.author: Matthew Lee

data.text:
I use both a tent & bivi. Depends on terrain & weather! https://ultralightoutdoorgear.co.uk/2021-ridge-raider-bivi/ https://www.google.co.uk/search?q=laser+pulse+tent&ie=UTF-8&oe=UTF-8&hl=en-gb&client=safari#fpstate=ive&vld=cid:eddbd817,vid:-No8wuaUEXE,st:0
Ridge Raider Bivi
ultralightoutdoorgear.co.uk
data.author: Mack Cormack

data.text: I have a ridge raider (shown above) used it earlier this year for first time and it was great. No rain luckily, and the 30mph wind I‚Äôd been cycling into for 90miles disappeared when I set up thank god but condensation was an issue if I touched it (which obviously I did). I‚Äôd say if going for one or two nights and if the weather looks good - then ridge raider is great. Other than that I‚Äôd probably look at a tent (and I‚Äôm after good suggestions there myself)
data.author: Joshua Samuel Allen

data.text: From the confines of an armchair looking out, I romanticise about sliding into a bivvy, warmed by a titanium mug of my favourite single malt and watching the stars. Then remember the nights when I actually took a bivvy and it blew a hoolie and pissed down all night! My fault for not looking at the weather forecastüòâ. I now keep to my Terra Nova Laser Competition 1.
data.author: Nick Miles

data.text: Tent if it's going to rain or you want a bit of space and comfort. Bivy if you want to go to sleep looking at the sunset/stars. Be warned! Leaping out of a bivy bag starkers and pulling on damp clothes whilst being enveloped by freezing cloud is both horrific and addictive üòÅ. A tent is better in every way. Except for the feeling of wind rippling against your body as a gale blows over your sleeping form.
data.author: Ed Fraser

data.text: fair points, entertainingly conveyedüëå
data.author: Sarah Dee

data.text: Bivvy is great for stealth and that "roughing" it feel. But I would take tarp as well. If weather turns you can create tarp tent (loads of YouTube tutorial vids)
data.author: David Morton

data.text: Being a water sports coach coach I have got change many many public places. For me previously comes after practically and temperature. If practical for me it will always be a hammock
data.author: Andy McMahon

data.text: Bivvy lighter and a bit more versatile, but these days tents are ~1kg and compact, better in poor weather imo, and more "homely" where a tarp feels like just a shelter. Also, midges
data.author: Henk Kommers

data.text: midges should be the very first thing mentioned in your post!!!!! I hate midges.
data.author: Simon Neuhoff

data.text: ha ha I've not had the displeasure recently, last camp was wet so none about. I do despise flies though
data.author: Henk Kommers

data.text: Do you do any research of your own ie by going on trips and finding out or do you spend your time thinking what questions you can ask next on forums?
data.author: Alex Maudorn

data.text: Small lightweight tent. Not much weight difference so what‚Äôs to be gained by a bivvy bag?Been there. Clearly in an emergency or if your in military (been there too). I just don‚Äôt see the point. If you want that bivvy feel under the stars, just leave the tent fly doors open. üëç
data.author: Thomas Magowan O'Moore

data.text: Used a British Army bivvy in the south of Spain this week, spent the first night sweating and batting away insects on the floor, second night I fashioned it into a hammock and had a few uncomfortable nights. So now I've tried bivvying in cold, wet and hot weather and all have been terrible experiences. I feel like unless it's dry and mild they are uncomfortable.
data.author: Douglas Crabtree

data.text: bivvis are magical on a sub zero clear night in the Highlands üòçüëå but never in summer up here ü¶üü¶üüòâ
data.author: Rosie Baxendine

data.text: I use a hammock that can be used as a bivy and a tarp that way I have all bases covered.
data.author: Matthew Wadham

data.text: Travel as light as possible. Having used both i would say a good quality lightweight tent is best for comfort. Bivy doesnt give you the option of somewhere to sit that is sheltered. Much nicer in wild weather to get into a tent than it is to sit under a tarp. It really depends on where you are going and what conditions you are likely to experience. Nice and dry take the bivi and tarp. Wet and windy take the tent.
data.author: Jim McNeil

data.text: I used a bivy with a Tarp when I cycled Cardiff to Bangor, I wild camped which was fantastic, however I came across a campsite and wanted to stay but because I didn‚Äôt have a tent I decided to move on. I‚Äôm doing the same trip this month and I‚Äôm going to see what the weathers like so I can make a decision tent or tarp
data.author: Dusty Miller

data.text: Both have their place for me. Bivvy and tarp are cheaper (alpkit) and a lot of fun in midge free summer situations. But as soon as risk of rain, tent all the way. Generally folks who don‚Äôt bivvy will say a tent is better and bang on about weight. I bivvy for the experience rather than the weight saving.
data.author: Dale Warren

data.text: Lightweight 2 man tent in summer and rain Bivvi and tarp in spring, autumn, winter or windy nights Hammock when there's trees!
data.author: Rosie Baxendine

data.text: so over a 2 month trip you accurately predict the weather?
data.author: Andy McMahon

data.text: if the question had included a timeline (such as you've just asked) then I'd have put a definitive answer - however it just asked for 1 person options üòÖ Ps. 2 man tent in case you're wondering üòâüëç
data.author: Rosie Baxendine

data.text: that‚Äôs the point it overnight with the family is very different to an expedition in the artic circle
data.author: Andy McMahon

data.text: obviously... ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
data.author: Rosie Baxendine

data.text: I have a bivy, a one man and a two man. I mainly use the two man just cos I like the room when it's raining and you're stuck in it. It's not like sleeping in a coffin like the other two are.
data.author: Pete McCarthy

data.text: For me- Tents for the win. Cause bugs. Bugs bugs bugs bugs. Did I say bugs? Bugs.
data.author: Simon Neuhoff

data.text: pro - light, compact con - wet/damp sleep Personally I go with compact 1-man tent and tarp to navigate various conditions. More versatile, and no minging nights. Essentially a bivvy is a piece of survival kit.
data.author: Lincs Hcrib

data.text: I suppose we just camp for fun anyway I use a Bivvy and tarp sometimes, cos you can use a tarp any where any time for anything my feet always end up sticking out of the end, have an old mod Bivvy bag So they stay dry, I got a Oex 1 man pretty tight fit but fun too. Try a bit of both, you can get some super cheap stuff now. Some people love s hammock but I hate dropping on the floor in the middle of the night! dd tarps are great for little tarps there are also loads of cheapies in go outdoors
data.author: Richard Morris

data.text: Where I‚Äôve ended up is: - Breathable bivvy with bug net that is held off your face is my favourite for perfect weather on an overnighter - Same bivvy plus light tarp is good for chance of rain but if it does occur only light rain and again mainly for an overnighter or trip where there will be limited downtime and wild camping - Tent for everything else
data.author: Hugh Robinson

data.text: You can get a spacious 2 man tent weighing 1.3 kg a lot better than a tarp.
data.author: Tony Bevan
